questions.question: What are the three types of stop consonants in Georgian?
questions.explanation: Georgian distinguishes three types of consonant sounds: Voiced (ბ, გ, დ), Aspirated (თ, ფ, ქ), and Ejective (კ, პ, ტ, წ, ჭ, ყ). This three-way system is unique and crucial for proper Georgian pronunciation.

questions.question: How do you produce an ejective consonant?

options.text: By closing your throat and creating a 'pop' sound

questions.explanation: Ejective consonants are made by closing your throat (vocal cords), building pressure, and then releasing with a distinctive 'pop' sound. This is what makes them different from aspirated consonants.

questions.question: What is the difference between თ [tʰ] and ტ [tʼ]?

options.text: თ is aspirated (with air), ტ is ejective (with pop)
თ is ejective, ტ is aspirated
თ is voiced, ტ is voiceless

questions.explanation: თ [tʰ] is aspirated - released with a puff of air. ტ [tʼ] is ejective - made by closing your throat and popping. These are completely different sounds in Georgian and can distinguish word meanings (e.g., თხა 'goat' vs ტბა 'lake').

questions.question: Match the consonants to their types:
questions.explanation: Voiced: ბ [b], გ [g]. Aspirated: თ [tʰ], ქ [kʰ]. Ejective: კ [kʼ], ტ [tʼ].

questions.question: What does the [ʰ] symbol in IPA represent?
questions.explanation: The [ʰ] symbol in IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) represents aspiration - a puff of air released when producing the consonant. Aspirated consonants in Georgian include თ [tʰ], ფ [pʰ], and ქ [kʰ].

questions.question: Which word uses an ejective consonant: თხა (goat) or კაცი (man)?
questions.explanation: კაცი [kʼatsi] (man) uses the ejective კ [kʼ]. თხა [tʰxa] (goat) uses the aspirated თ [tʰ]. Notice how the ejective has a 'pop' sound while the aspirated has a puff of air.

questions.question: Why is it important to master the three-way difference early?

options.text: Pronunciation habits become 'fossilized' and hard to change later
Native speakers won't understand you otherwise

questions.explanation: Pronunciation fossilization is a real phenomenon. If incorrect pronunciation habits become ingrained early, they become very difficult to change later. This is why we dedicate significant time to mastering ejective consonants from the beginning!
